001package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost;
002
003import static java.lang.Math.exp;
004import static java.lang.Math.floor;
005import static java.lang.Math.pow;
006
007import org.immutables.value.Value;
008
009import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.StochasticModel;
010import io.github.ai4ci.util.Conversions;
011import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
012
013/**
014 * A stochastic difference equation model of in-host viral dynamics and immune
015 * response.
016 *
017 * <p>
018 * This model simulates the discrete-time evolution of key compartments:
019 * <ul>
020 * <li><b>Virions</b>: free viral particles,</li>
021 * <li><b>Target cells</b>: susceptible, exposed (latently infected), infected,
022 * and removed,</li>
023 * <li><b>Immune cells</b>: dormant, priming, and active (effector).</li>
024 * </ul>
025 *
026 * <p>
027 * Transitions between compartments are modeled as stochastic events using
028 * binomial and Poisson sampling, capturing demographic and interaction noise.
029 * The model supports external inputs such as:
030 * <ul>
031 * <li>New virion exposure (infection),</li>
032 * <li>Immunization (immune priming).</li>
033 * </ul>
034 *
035 * <p>
036 * The dynamics are governed by per-time-step rates, converted to probabilities
037 * via \( p = 1 - e^{-r} \). This ensures consistency with continuous-time
038 * interpretations while enabling efficient discrete simulation.
039 *
040 * @see <a href=
041 *      "https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/93852/sum-of-bernoulli-variables-with-different-success-probabilities">Poisson
042 *      Binomial Distribution</a>
043 * @see <a href=
044 *      "https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/32800/probability-distribution-of-coverage-of-a-set-after-x-randomly-independently">Set
045 *      Coverage Problem</a>
046 *
047 *      <img src="stochastic-model.png"
048 *      alt="Diagram of InHostStochasticState compartments and transitions" />
049 *
050 */
051@Value.Immutable
052public interface InHostStochasticState
053                extends InHostModelState<StochasticModel> {
054
055        /**
056         * Gets the baseline viral infection rate.
057         *
058         * <p>
059         * This rate controls how efficiently viral particles infect susceptible
060         * target cells. Higher rates lead to more rapid target cell depletion and
061         * faster infection progression.
062         *
063         * @return the baseline viral infection rate
064         */
065        @Value.Redacted
066        double getBaselineViralInfectionRate();
067
068        /**
069         * Gets the baseline viral replication rate.
070         *
071         * <p>
072         * This rate controls how quickly infected cells produce new viral particles.
073         * Higher rates lead to faster viral load increase and more rapid infection
074         * progression.
075         *
076         * @return the baseline viral replication rate
077         */
078        @Value.Redacted
079        double getBaselineViralReplicationRate();
080
081        /**
082         * Gets the total number of immune cells in the system.
083         *
084         * <p>
085         * Calculated as the product of target cells and immune-target ratio.
086         * Represents the total immune capacity, distributed across dormant, priming,
087         * and active states.
088         *
089         * @return the total immune cell count
090         */
091        @Value.Default
092        default Integer getImmune() {
093                return (int) (this.getTargets() * this.getImmuneTargetRatio());
094        }
095
096        /**
097         * Gets the activation rate for immune cell priming in response to infection.
098         *
099         * <p>
100         * This rate controls how quickly dormant immune cells transition to priming
101         * state when exposed to infected or exposed target cells. Higher rates lead
102         * to faster immune response initiation.
103         *
104         * @return the immune activation rate
105         */
106        double getImmuneActivationRate();
107
108        /**
109         * Gets the count of active effector immune cells.
110         *
111         * <p>
112         * Active immune cells are responsible for viral neutralization and infected
113         * cell clearance. Their activity level modulates infection and clearance
114         * rates throughout the simulation.
115         *
116         * @return the count of active immune cells
117         */
118        int getImmuneActive();
119
120        /**
121         * Computes immune activity as the fraction of immune cells that are active
122         * (effector) state.
123         *
124         * <p>
125         * Defined as: \[ I_{\text{activity}} =
126         * \frac{I_{\text{active}}}{I_{\text{total}}} \] where \( I_{\text{total}} =
127         * \text{floor}(T_{\text{total}} \cdot r_I) \), and \( r_I \) is the
128         * immune-to-target ratio. This normalized activity modulates viral clearance
129         * and infection rates.
130         *
131         * @return immune activity as a fraction of maximum capacity
132         */
133        @Override @Value.Derived
134        default double getImmuneActivity() {
135                return ((double) this.getImmuneActive()) / this.getImmune();
136        }
137
138        /**
139         * Computes the number of immune cells in the dormant (naive or memory)
140         * state.
141         *
142         * <p>
143         * Defined as: \[ I_{\text{dormant}} = I_{\text{total}} - I_{\text{priming}}
144         * - I_{\text{active}} \] These cells can be activated by infection or
145         * immunization.
146         *
147         * @return count of dormant immune cells
148         */
149        @Value.Derived
150        default int getImmuneDormant() {
151                return this.getImmune() - this.getImmunePriming()
152                                - this.getImmuneActive();
153        }
154
155        /**
156         * Gets the count of immune cells in priming state.
157         *
158         * <p>
159         * Priming cells have recognized antigen but are not yet fully active
160         * effectors. They represent the intermediate stage in immune activation
161         * between dormant and active states.
162         *
163         * @return the count of priming immune cells
164         */
165        int getImmunePriming();
166
167        /**
168         * Gets the ratio of immune cells to target cells in the system.
169         *
170         * <p>
171         * This ratio determines the baseline immune capacity relative to the target
172         * cell population. Higher ratios indicate stronger innate immune responses.
173         *
174         * @return the immune-to-target cell ratio
175         */
176        double getImmuneTargetRatio();
177
178        /**
179         * Gets the waning rate for active immune cells transitioning to senescence.
180         *
181         * <p>
182         * This rate determines how quickly active effector immune cells lose their
183         * effectiveness and transition to a senescent state. Lower rates result in
184         * longer-lasting immune protection.
185         *
186         * @return the immune waning rate
187         */
188        double getImmuneWaningRate();
189
190        /**
191         * Gets the probability that an exposed cell becomes a chronic infection
192         * carrier.
193         *
194         * <p>
195         * This probability determines whether exposed cells avoid immune clearance
196         * and remain in a latent reservoir, potentially leading to persistent or
197         * chronic infections.
198         *
199         * @return the chronic infection carrier probability
200         */
201        double getInfectionCarrierProbability();
202
203        /**
204         * Computes a proxy for disease severity based on the proportion of
205         * non-susceptible target cells.
206         *
207         * <p>
208         * Severity is defined as: \[ S(t) = \frac{T_{\text{total}} -
209         * T_{\text{susceptible}}(t) - T_{\text{exposed}}(t)}{T_{\text{total}}} \]
210         * which reflects the fraction of targets that have been infected and
211         * progressed beyond latency. This assumes severity correlates with
212         * cumulative tissue damage.
213         *
214         * @return the proportion of targets that are infected or removed
215         */
216        @Override @Value.Derived
217        default double getNormalisedSeverity() {
218                // The interpretation of this number depends on the calibration
219                // double baselinePercent = this.getConfig().getTargetSymptomsCutoff();
220                var currentPercent = ((double) this.getTargets()
221                                - this.getTargetSusceptible() - this.getTargetExposed())
222                                / this.getTargets();
223                return currentPercent; // Conversions.oddsRatio(currentPercent,
224                                                                                // baselinePercent);
225        }
226
227        @Override @Value.Derived
228        /**
229         * The viral load is the number of newly produced virions, i.e. the total
230         * virions in the person excluding those innoculating the person. Large
231         * innoculations can't be excluded completely as they do not immediately
232         * infect cells.
233         *
234         * @return
235         */
236        default double getNormalisedViralLoad() {
237                var tmp = Conversions.rateRatio(
238                                this.getVirionsProduced(), this.getVirionsDiseaseCutoff()
239                );
240                return tmp;
241        }
242
243        /**
244         * Gets the count of exposed (latently infected) target cells.
245         *
246         * <p>
247         * These cells have been infected but are not yet actively producing virions.
248         * They may progress to infected state, be cleared by immune response, or
249         * remain as chronic carriers.
250         *
251         * @return the count of exposed target cells
252         */
253        int getTargetExposed();
254
255        /**
256         * Gets the count of infected target cells actively producing virions.
257         *
258         * <p>
259         * These cells are the primary source of new viral particles through
260         * replication. They contribute to disease severity and can be cleared by
261         * immune response or cellular removal processes.
262         *
263         * @return the count of infected target cells
264         */
265        int getTargetInfected();
266
267        /**
268         * Gets the recovery rate for removed target cells returning to susceptible
269         * state.
270         *
271         * <p>
272         * This rate controls the regeneration of target cells from the removed pool,
273         * representing tissue repair and cell turnover processes. Higher rates lead
274         * to faster recovery of susceptible cell populations.
275         *
276         * @return the target cell recovery rate
277         */
278        double getTargetRecoveryRate();
279
280        /**
281         * Computes the number of target cells that are no longer susceptible due to
282         * recovery, death, or removal.
283         *
284         * <p>
285         * This is derived from conservation of total targets: \[ T_{\text{removed}}
286         * = T_{\text{total}} - T_{\text{susceptible}} - T_{\text{exposed}} -
287         * T_{\text{infected}} \]
288         *
289         * @return the count of removed (non-susceptible, non-infected) target cells
290         */
291        @Value.Derived
292        default int getTargetRemoved() {
293                return this.getTargets() - this.getTargetSusceptible()
294                                - this.getTargetExposed() - this.getTargetInfected();
295        }
296
297        /**
298         * Gets the total number of target cells available for viral infection.
299         *
300         * <p>
301         * This represents the fixed pool size of susceptible cells that can be
302         * infected. The total target count remains constant throughout the
303         * simulation, with individual cells transitioning between susceptible,
304         * exposed, infected, and removed states.
305         *
306         * @return the total number of target cells
307         */
308        int getTargets();
309
310        /**
311         * Gets the count of susceptible target cells available for infection.
312         *
313         * <p>
314         * These are healthy cells that can be infected by viral particles. The
315         * susceptible pool decreases as cells become exposed and increases as
316         * removed cells recover.
317         *
318         * @return the count of susceptible target cells
319         */
320        int getTargetSusceptible();
321
322        // StochasticModel getConfig();
323
324        /**
325         * Gets the current simulation time step.
326         *
327         * <p>
328         * Represents the discrete time index in the simulation. Each time step
329         * typically corresponds to one day in the infection progression timeline.
330         *
331         * @return the current time step
332         */
333        @Override
334        int getTime();
335
336        /**
337         * Gets the current count of free viral particles (virions) in circulation.
338         *
339         * <p>
340         * This includes both infectious and non-infectious viral particles. Virions
341         * can infect target cells, be neutralized by immune cells, or be produced by
342         * infected cells.
343         *
344         * @return the current virion count
345         */
346        int getVirions();
347
348        /**
349         * Gets the disease cutoff value for virion normalization.
350         *
351         * <p>
352         * This parameter defines the reference virion count used to normalize viral
353         * load measurements. It represents a clinically relevant threshold for
354         * disease severity assessment.
355         *
356         * @return the virion disease cutoff value
357         */
358        @Value.Redacted
359        int getVirionsDiseaseCutoff();
360
361        /**
362         * Gets the count of newly produced virions in the current time step.
363         *
364         * <p>
365         * This represents the viral replication output from infected target cells.
366         * Used to distinguish between newly produced virions and those from previous
367         * time steps or external exposure.
368         *
369         * @return the count of newly produced virions
370         */
371        int getVirionsProduced();
372
373        /**
374         * Advances the in-host state by one time step using stochastic difference
375         * equations.
376         *
377         * <p>
378         * The update models the following biological processes:
379         * <ul>
380         * <li><b>Viral replication:</b> Poisson-distributed production from infected
381         * cells,</li>
382         * <li><b>Neutralization:</b> Binomial clearance by active immunity,</li>
383         * <li><b>Infection:</b> Stochastic infection of susceptible targets,</li>
384         * <li><b>Immune activation:</b> Priming and activation cascades,</li>
385         * <li><b>Cell turnover:</b> Recovery of target cells and waning of
386         * immunity.</li>
387         * </ul>
388         *
389         * <p>
390         * <u>Infection of Target Cells</u>
391         * </p>
392         * The number of target cells that interact with virions is modeled using the
393         * <i>coverage problem</i> from combinatorics. When \( n \) virions sample
394         * from \( S \) susceptible targets with replacement, the expected number of
395         * unique targets hit is: \[ \mathbb{E}[\text{interacted}] = S \left(1 -
396         * e^{-n/S}\right) \] This approximates the solution to the classic problem
397         * of set coverage after independent random sampling
398         * (<a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/32800">see
399         * reference</a>).
400         *
401         * <p>
402         * From these interacting targets, a binomial sample determines how many
403         * become <i>exposed</i>, with probability \( p_{\text{infection}} = 1 -
404         * e^{-r_{\text{infect}} \cdot S/T} \).
405         *
406         * <p>
407         * <u>Immune Dynamics</u>
408         * </p>
409         * Immune activation depends on the burden of exposed and infected cells: \[
410         * p_{\text{priming}} = 1 - e^{-r_{\text{prime}} \cdot (T_e + T_i)/T} \]
411         * Active immunity wanes at rate \( r_{\text{waning}} \), modeled as a
412         * binomial decay process.
413         *
414         * <p>
415         * <u>Chronic Infection</u>
416         * </p>
417         * A fixed probability \( p_{\text{chronic}} \) determines whether an exposed
418         * cell avoids immune clearance and remains in a latent reservoir.
419         *
420         * @param rng              the random sampler for stochastic transitions
421         * @param virionDose       the external virion exposure, scaled by disease
422         *                         cutoff
423         * @param immunisationDose the immunization strength, interpreted as fraction
424         *                         of dormant immunity to prime
425         * @return a new state advanced by one time unit
426         */
427        @Override
428        default InHostStochasticState update(
429                        Sampler rng, double virionDose, double immunisationDose
430        ) { // , double viralActivityModifier, double immuneModifier) {
431
432                var virionsDx = this.getVirionsDiseaseCutoff();
433
434                var time = this.getTime();
435                // This update function is called when the history has been updated,
436                // as part of the update to the patientState so
437                // exposure will be as determined by current contact network.
438                var virionExposure = (int) virionDose * virionsDx;
439
440                var immunePriming = (int) floor(
441                                immunisationDose * this.getImmuneDormant()
442                );
443
444                // TODO: review need for host immunity and viral activity modifiers
445                var hostImmunity = 1D;
446                Double viralActivity = 1D;
447
448                // Viral factors are shared across the model
449                var rate_infection = this.getBaselineViralInfectionRate()
450                                * viralActivity;
451                Double rate_virion_replication = pow(
452                                this.getBaselineViralReplicationRate(), viralActivity
453                );
454                var rate_infected_given_exposed = rate_virion_replication;
455                // Host factors
456
457                var ratio_immune_target = this.getImmuneTargetRatio() * hostImmunity;
458                var rate_priming_given_infected = this.getImmuneActivationRate()
459                                * hostImmunity; // user(1)
460                Double rate_active_given_priming = rate_priming_given_infected;
461
462                var rate_neutralization = rate_virion_replication;
463                var rate_cellular_removal = rate_neutralization;
464
465                Double rate_target_recovery = this.getTargetRecoveryRate() * hostImmunity; // user(1/7);
466
467                Double rate_senescence_given_active = this.getImmuneWaningRate()
468                                * (1.0 / hostImmunity); // user(1/150)
469
470                Double p_propensity_chronic = this.getInfectionCarrierProbability(); // user(0)
471
472                // Derived
473                Double p_neutralization = 1 - exp(
474                                -rate_neutralization * this.getImmuneActive()
475                                                / (double) this.getImmune()
476                );
477                Double p_infection = 1 - exp(
478                                -rate_infection * this.getTargetSusceptible() / this.getTargets()
479                );
480
481                Integer virions_added = rng
482                                .poisson(rate_virion_replication * this.getTargetInfected());
483                Integer virions_neutralized = rng
484                                .binom(this.getVirions(), p_neutralization);
485                Integer virions_infecting = rng
486                                .binom(this.getVirions() - virions_neutralized, p_infection);
487
488//                # virions_infecting is a sample size and targets_susceptible is a pool size #
489//                coverage of the pool by repeated sampling with replacement is given by: #
490//                p_target_infected = 1-(1-1/target_susceptible)^virions_infecting # this is
491//                not a standard way of doing this # because multiple viral particles can
492//                infect a single host but not vice versa # so a standard collision model is
493//                not applicable. #
494//                https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/32800/probability-distribution-of-
495//                coverage-of-a-set-after-x-independently-randomly/32816#32816
496
497                // Targets - exposed
498                Integer target_interacted = (int) floor(
499                        // virions_infecting.doubleValue() *
500//                                      (1-
501//                                              pow(
502//                                                      virions_infecting.doubleValue()/(1+virions_infecting.doubleValue()),
503//                                                      (double) getTargetSusceptible()
504//                                              )
505//                                      )
506//                                      (double) getTargetSusceptible() *
507//                                      (1-
508//                                              pow(
509//                                                      ((double) getTargetSusceptible()-1)/((double) getTargetSusceptible()),
510//                                                      virions_infecting.doubleValue()
511//                                              )
512//                                      )
513                                this.getTargetSusceptible() * (1 - exp(
514                                                -virions_infecting.doubleValue()
515                                                                / (this.getTargetSusceptible())
516                                ))
517                );
518                Integer target_newly_exposed = rng.binom(target_interacted, p_infection);
519                Double p_target_recovery = Conversions
520                                .probabilityFromRate(rate_target_recovery);
521                Integer target_recovered = rng
522                                .binom(this.getTargetRemoved(), p_target_recovery);
523                // Targets - infected
524                Double p_infected_given_exposed = Conversions
525                                .probabilityFromRate(rate_infected_given_exposed);
526                Double p_target_cellular_removal = Conversions.probabilityFromRate(
527                                rate_cellular_removal * this.getImmuneActive() / (this.getTargets())
528                );
529                Integer target_exposed_removal = rng.binom(
530                                this.getTargetExposed(),
531                                (1 - p_propensity_chronic) * p_target_cellular_removal
532                );
533                Integer target_start_infected = rng.binom(
534                                this.getTargetExposed() - target_exposed_removal,
535                                p_infected_given_exposed
536                );
537                Integer target_infected_removed = rng
538                                .binom(this.getTargetInfected(), p_target_cellular_removal);
539
540                // Immunity - priming
541                Double p_priming_given_infected = Conversions.probabilityFromRate(
542                                rate_priming_given_infected
543                                                * (this.getTargetExposed() + this.getTargetInfected())
544                                                / this.getTargets()
545                );
546                Integer immune_start_priming = rng
547                                .binom(this.getImmuneDormant(), p_priming_given_infected);
548                Double p_active_given_priming = Conversions
549                                .probabilityFromRate(rate_active_given_priming);
550                Integer immune_start_active = rng
551                                .binom(this.getImmunePriming(), p_active_given_priming);
552                // Immunity - active
553                Double p_senescence_given_active = Conversions
554                                .probabilityFromRate(rate_senescence_given_active);
555                Integer immune_senescence = rng
556                                .binom(this.getImmuneActive(), p_senescence_given_active);
557
558                if (immunePriming > this.getImmune()) {
559                        immunePriming = this.getImmune();
560                }
561
562                return ImmutableInHostStochasticState.builder().from(this)
563                                .setTime(time + 1)
564                                // Virions
565                                .setVirions(
566                                                this.getVirions() - virions_neutralized - virions_infecting
567                                                                + virions_added + virionExposure
568                                )
569                                .setVirionsProduced(
570                                                this.getVirions() - virions_neutralized - virions_infecting
571                                                                + virions_added
572                                )
573                                // Targets
574                                .setTargetSusceptible(
575                                                this.getTargetSusceptible() - target_newly_exposed
576                                                                + target_recovered
577                                )
578                                .setTargetExposed(
579                                                this.getTargetExposed() + target_newly_exposed
580                                                                - target_exposed_removal - target_start_infected
581                                )
582                                .setTargetInfected(
583                                                this.getTargetInfected() + target_start_infected
584                                                                - target_infected_removed
585                                )
586                                // Immune
587                                .setImmune(
588                                                (int) floor(this.getTargets() * ratio_immune_target)
589                                                                - immunePriming
590                                )
591                                .setImmunePriming(
592                                                this.getImmunePriming() + immune_start_priming
593                                                                - immune_start_active + immunePriming
594                                )
595                                .setImmuneActive(
596                                                this.getImmuneActive() + immune_start_active
597                                                                - immune_senescence
598                                ).build();
599        }
600
601}
602
603/*
604 * Yes  while the `InHostStochasticState` model is a thoughtful and
605 * computationally efficient discrete-time stochastic formulation, there are
606 * several **biological and mathematical critiques** of the relationship between
607 * *virions* and *target cells*, particularly in how infection dynamics are
608 * modeled. These critiques stem from the interplay of assumptions about
609 * interaction mechanics, population scaling, and biological realism.
610 *
611 * Lets analyze the key aspects using insights from the provided knowledge base
612 * (Poisson binomial, coverage problem) and standard virological principles.
613 *
614 * ---
615 *
616 * ###  1. **Infection Mechanism: From Virions to Target Cell Exposure**
617 *
618 * The core infection step uses this logic:
619 *
620 * ```java Integer target_interacted = (int) floor( (double)
621 * getTargetSusceptible() * (1 - exp( - virions_infecting.doubleValue() /
622 * ((double) getTargetSusceptible()) )) ); Integer target_newly_exposed =
623 * rng.binom(target_interacted, p_infection); ```
624 *
625 * This combines: - A **coverage model** (from the Math StackExchange
626 * reference): The expected number of distinct susceptible cells that "interact"
627 * with virions is: \[ \mathbb{E}[C] = S \left(1 - e^{-n/S}\right) \] where \( S
628 * = T_{\text{susceptible}} \), \( n = \text{virions\_infecting} \).  This is
629 * **correct** for modeling the expected number of unique targets hit under
630 * independent sampling with replacement.
631 *
632 * - Then, only a **fraction** of those interacting cells become exposed, via a
633 * binomial draw with probability \( p_{\text{infection}} \).
634 *
635 * But here lies the **critique**:
636 *
637 * >  **Double-counting of infection probability**: > The model applies a
638 * second infection probability \( p_{\text{infection}} \) *after* already
639 * modeling exposure via virion contact.
640 *
641 * In reality, if a virion "interacts" with a cell in the coverage model, that
642 * interaction should already encode the **probability of successful
643 * infection**. But instead: - `virions_infecting` is a binomial sample based on
644 * a global infection probability, - Then `target_interacted` computes how many
645 * cells are hit, - Then `target_newly_exposed` applies *another* infection
646 * probability.
647 *
648 * This **separates binding from infection**  which could be valid  but the
649 * current structure risks **under- or over-estimating infection efficiency**
650 * unless carefully calibrated.
651 *
652 * ---
653 *
654 * ###  Suggested Fix: Integrate Infection Probability into Virion Efficacy
655 *
656 * Instead of: 1. Sample `virions_infecting = binom(virions, p_infection)` 2.
657 * Compute `target_interacted = S(1 - e^{-n/S})` 3. Then `target_newly_exposed =
658 * binom(target_interacted, p_infection)`
659 *
660 * Do one of the following:
661 *
662 * #### Option A: Let each virion have a chance to infect, and use coverage as a
663 * mechanical limit ```java // Effective infectious virions int n_eff =
664 * rng.binom(getVirions(), p_infection_per_virion);
665 *
666 * // Number of distinct cells hit int target_interacted = (int) floor(S * (1 -
667 * exp(-n_eff / (double) S)));
668 *
669 * // All hit cells become exposed (binding  infection) target_newly_exposed =
670 * target_interacted; ```
671 *
672 * #### Option B: Use a per-cell infection probability based on virion load Use
673 * a **Poisson approximation** to the number of virions hitting a cell: -
674 * Average hits per cell: \( \lambda = n / S \) - Probability a cell is hit at
675 * least once: \( 1 - e^{-\lambda} \) - Then, probability of infection given
676 * hit: \( p_{\text{inf|hit}} \) - So total infection probability per cell: \[
677 * p_{\text{cell infected}} = (1 - e^{-\lambda}) \cdot p_{\text{inf|hit}} \] -
678 * Then: \[ \mathbb{E}[\text{newly exposed}] = S \cdot p_{\text{cell infected}}
679 * \] - Draw: `target_newly_exposed = rng.binom(S, p_cell_infected)`
680 *
681 * This avoids the intermediate "interacted" state and is more directly
682 * interpretable.
683 *
684 * ---
685 *
686 * ###  2. **Biological Interpretation of "Virions" vs. "Infectious Units"**
687 *
688 * The model tracks `getVirions()` as a count, but: - Not all virions are
689 * infectious, - The `p_infection` term tries to correct for this, - But its
690 * applied globally, not per interaction.
691 *
692 * This leads to **nonlinear scaling issues**: doubling virions doesnt double
693 * infection probability due to the `1 - exp(-n/S)` saturation.
694 *
695 * But if `virions` includes non-infectious particles (which they usually do),
696 * then: - The model should distinguish **total virions** from **infectious
697 * units**, - Or scale `p_infection` appropriately with virion quality.
698 *
699 * Otherwise, the same `virionsDx` (disease cutoff) may not generalize across
700 * variants or hosts.
701 *
702 * ---
703 *
704 * ###  3. **Immune Clearance vs. Viral Replication: Scale Dependence**
705 *
706 * The immune neutralization is modeled as: ```java p_neutralization = 1 -
707 * exp(-rate_neutralization * getImmuneActive() / (double) getImmune()) ``` and
708 * then: ```java virions_neutralized = rng.binom(getVirions(), p_neutralization)
709 * ```
710 *
711 * This assumes: - The neutralization rate scales with **fraction of active
712 * immunity**, - But the effect is applied to the **total virion pool**.
713 *
714 * However, this creates a **mismatch in scaling**: - Immune cells act locally
715 * (e.g., in tissue), - But virions may be systemic.
716 *
717 * If the number of virions grows faster than immune capacity (e.g., in
718 * immunosuppressed hosts), the model may **underestimate viral escape** unless
719 * rates are carefully tuned.
720 *
721 * Better: Model neutralization as a **bimolecular reaction**: \[
722 * \text{neutralized} \sim \text{Binomial}\left(V, 1 - e^{-k \cdot I}\right) \]
723 * where \( k \) is a clearance constant, and \( I = \text{immune active} \),
724 * without normalizing by total immune capacity  unless that total is fixed.
725 *
726 * ---
727 *
728 * ###  4. **Target Cell Recovery: Biologically Unjustified?**
729 *
730 * ```java Integer target_recovered = rng.binom(getTargetRemoved(),
731 * p_target_recovery); ``` This assumes removed (e.g., dead or differentiated)
732 * cells can "recover" back to susceptible.
733 *
734 * But in most viral infections: - Dead cells dont come back, - Recovery
735 * implies **new cell production** (e.g., hematopoiesis, epithelial turnover), -
736 * So `target_recovered` should be drawn from a **source pool**, not from
737 * `removed`.
738 *
739 * Better: Replace with: ```java target_recovered = rng.poisson(rate_recovery *
740 * getTargetRemoved()); ``` or even better, introduce a **progenitor
741 * compartment** if modeling long-term dynamics.
742 *
743 * Alternatively, if turnover is slow, just dont recover them  let immunity
744 * handle protection.
745 *
746 * ---
747 *
748 * ###  5. **Stochasticity vs. Population Size: Risk of Over-Discreteness**
749 *
750 * Because all transitions are binomial or Poisson, the model is **fully
751 * discrete**  good for small populations.
752 *
753 * But if `getTargets()` is large (e.g., millions of cells), the stochastic
754 * noise may be too small to matter, and a **deterministic ODE approximation**
755 * would be faster.
756 *
757 * Conversely, if `getTargets()` is small (e.g., localized infection), the model
758 * is appropriate.
759 *
760 *  **Recommendation**: Document expected scale (e.g., 10010,000 cells) and
761 * validate that binomial sampling doesnt induce artificial extinction or
762 * explosion.
763 *
764 * ---
765 *
766 * ###  Summary of Critiques
767 *
768 * | Issue | Problem | Suggested Fix | |------|-------|---------------| |
769 * **Double infection probability** | Applying `p_infection` twice (on virions
770 * and on cells) | Fold infection probability into per-cell or per-virion
771 * efficacy | | **Virion vs. infectious unit** | Not all virions infect; model
772 * lacks distinction | Introduce `infectious_ratio` or scale `p_infection` | |
773 * **Immune normalization** | Clearance depends on fraction active, not absolute
774 * count | Use absolute immune effector count unless constrained | | **Target
775 * cell recovery** | "Removed" cells becoming susceptible again | Model
776 * regeneration separately, or remove recovery | | **Scaling behavior** | May
777 * not generalize across population sizes | Document intended scale; consider
778 * hybrid models |
779 *
780 * ---
781 *
782 * ###  Final Verdict
783 *
784 * The model is **mechanistically sound at a high level**, especially in its use
785 * of: - The **coverage problem** to model stochastic exposure, - The **Poisson
786 * binomial intuition** for independent events, - Discrete stochastic sampling
787 * for realism.
788 *
789 * However, the **infection submodel** could be simplified and made more
790 * biologically coherent by **removing redundant probability layers** and
791 * ensuring that the **meaning of "virions" and "targets"** is consistent across
792 * processes.
793 *
794 * With those refinements, it would be a robust and interpretable in-host
795 * framework.
796 */
